what.title: What is a profile?
what.ui_picture: There is a default picture per gender. You can upload a real photo if available.
what.ui_name: The example shows ‚ÄúROMANIAN BIOGRAPHY‚Äù. If the profile represents a public figure, a yellow star appears next to the name.
what.ui_life: Under the name you‚Äôll see ‚ÄúBirth date ‚Äì death date‚Äù. If the person is alive, it shows ‚Äúliving‚Äù. In parentheses you may see the age (e.g., ‚Äú(? years)‚Äù) only when both dates exist.
what.ui_tree_ref: ‚ÄúTree ref: CUB-01‚Äù is the profile identifier. Next to it, a tree icon with a number (e.g., 5) shows how many people are connected in this person‚Äôs family.
what.ui_actions: Includes the blue family tree button linking to the tree page, a share button, a delete button (visible only to the owner), a Copy button to propose a duplicate, an Eye button to view potential duplicates, and a Star button to see connections to public figures.
what.ui_owner: The user who owns the profile can edit fields, add/remove data, manage relationships, and delete the profile.
what.p1: A profile represents a person‚Äîliving or deceased‚Äîand it‚Äôs the starting point for building family relationships, attaching sources, and documenting key life events.
what.p2: Each profile has an owner (the user who created it or to whom it was assigned). The owner has full control: they can edit any fields, add or remove data, manage relationships, and delete the profile.
what.p3: Profiles link to each other through relationships (parent, child, spouse/partner, etc.). As you attach relatives, the family tree builds up automatically.
what.p4: You can report and resolve duplicates: either copy a link to a suspected duplicate, or use the duplicates view to review them.

section1.title: What is a place and how to search/create it
section1.p1: Places are essential to anchor people and events in time. They can be cities, towns, regions, or countries ‚Äî modern or historical. When creating a new place, fill in both current and historical data where relevant. This helps identify places that changed names or borders over time (e.g., ‚ÄúGhiris‚Äù is the old name for modern-day C√¢mpia Turzii).
section1.p2: Each place has six key fields:
list: Historical country (e.g., ‚ÄúPrincipality of Transylvania‚Äù, ‚ÄúYugoslavia‚Äù, ‚ÄúPrincipality of Moldavia‚Äù, etc.)
section1.p3: When searching while editing a profile or a burial, type a few characters ‚Äî if the place exists, you‚Äôll get suggestions (settlements, counties, or countries). If you‚Äôre unsure, pick a higher-level unit (county/country) or click ‚ÄúCreate new place‚Äù. The more details you add ‚Äî especially for historical places ‚Äî the more helpful it becomes to others.

section2.title: Place details page
section2.p1: A place page shows a map (on the left) with the current coordinates and two tabs (on the right) to explore related content.

tabs.label: Profiles
tabs.desc: People born, living or otherwise associated with the place. Use the letter index above the list to filter by initial.

tabs.label: Cemeteries
tabs.desc: All cemeteries tagged within this place. From each cemetery you can view burials and, if permitted, add or edit details.

section2.p3: The map provides geographic context to historical data. Even if a name changed (e.g., Roman ‚ÄúNapoca‚Äù ‚Üí modern ‚ÄúCluj-Napoca‚Äù), coordinates connect past and present. Zoom to explore nearby settlements or other places in the same county.

section3.title: Cemeteries & Burial Sites
section3.p1: A ‚Äúcemetery‚Äù in RoBio means any burial site: organized cemetery, churchyard, monastery grounds, military plot, ossuary/crypt, or even a single isolated grave on a hill/field/forest. What matters is the exact spot where the person was buried.
section3.search_p1: Use the first field to search and select an existing cemetery. If it doesn‚Äôt exist, click ‚ÄúCreate cemetery‚Äù.
optional: Place (settlement) ‚Äî if it belongs to a known locality
examples: ‚ÄúLa ColoanƒÉ Cemetery‚Äù ‚Äî C√¢mpia Turzii (Cluj): precise coordinates; Place can be set to C√¢mpia Turzii.
Isolated hill grave (no locality): provide only lat/lon; you may leave Name and Place empty.
notes: If you don‚Äôt know the name or locality, still create the cemetery with coordinates ‚Äî you can fill missing fields later.
For accuracy, drop the pin at a high zoom level (ideally entrance or site center).
You can link the cemetery to a Place later once the locality/region is confirmed.
